message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Azathioprine is a prodrug that is converted to its active form by hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyl transferase (HGPRT). Thus, a deficiency of this enzyme would diminish the therapeutic effect of azathioprine.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Azathioprine is a prodrug that is converted to 6-mercaptopurine, which is then metabolized by hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyl transferase (HGPRT) to active metabolites. Therefore, a deficiency in HGPRT would diminish the therapeutic effect of azathioprine.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Azathioprine is metabolized by hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyl transferase (HGPRT), so a deficiency of this enzyme would diminish its therapeutic effect. Xanthine oxidase is involved in the metabolism of allopurinol, thymidylate synthase is involved in DNA synthesis and is targeted by chemotherapeutic agents, and phosphoribosyl pyrophosphate synthetase is involved in purine and pyrimidine synthesis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Azathioprine is a prodrug that is converted to its active form by the enzyme hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyl transferase. A deficiency of this enzyme would diminish the therapeutic effect of azathioprine. Xanthine oxidase is involved in the metabolism and clearance of azathioprine, but a deficiency of this enzyme would actually increase the risk of toxicity from the drug. Thymidylate synthase and phosphoribosyl pyrophosphate synthetase are not directly involved in the metabolism of azathioprine.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Azathioprine is a prodrug that is converted to 6-mercaptopurine, which is then metabolized by hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyl transferase (HGPRT) to its active form. A deficiency of HGPRT would diminish the therapeutic effect of azathioprine.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Azathioprine is a prodrug that is converted to 6-mercaptopurine (6-MP) by the enzyme hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyl transferase (HGPRT). Therefore, a deficiency of HGPRT would diminish the therapeutic effect of azathioprine.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Azathioprine is converted to 6-mercaptopurine, which is then metabolized by Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyl transferase (HGPRT), so a deficiency of this enzyme would diminish the therapeutic effect of the drug.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Azathioprine is a prodrug that is metabolized in vivo to 6-MP, which is subsequently converted to active metabolites. The enzyme that converts 6-MP to its active metabolites is Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyl transferase. Therefore, deficiency of this enzyme would diminish the therapeutic effect of azathioprine.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Azathioprine is a prodrug that is metabolized by the enzyme hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyl transferase (HGPRT) to mercaptopurine. Deficiency of HGPRT would lead to diminished therapeutic effect of azathioprine. Xanthine oxidase deficiency would lead to increased toxicity of mercaptopurine. Thymidylate synthase is not involved in the metabolism of azathioprine. Phosphoribosyl pyrophosphate synthetase is involved in the synthesis of purines, but not in the metabolism of azathioprine.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Azathioprine is converted to 6-mercaptopurine in the body, and then to the active metabolite 6-thioGTP by the enzyme hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyl transferase (HGPRT). Therefore, a deficiency in HGPRT activity diminishes the therapeutic effect of azathioprine.
